title: Mid Wales River Adventure
tagline: Kayak, swim, and fish on hidden rivers
suitableFor: Active individuals and couples who enjoy being outdoors and don't mind getting wet. Some experience with paddling is helpful but not essential.
notSuitableFor: Those with limited mobility, very young children (under 8), or anyone who dislikes being outdoors in potentially wet weather.

stops.title: Kayaking on the River Wye
stops.description: Enjoy a guided kayaking tour along a scenic stretch of the River Wye. Paddle past rolling hills and keep an eye out for local wildlife.

wetAlt.title: Elan Valley Visitor Centre
wetAlt.description: Learn about the history and ecology of the Elan Valley reservoirs in the interactive visitor centre.

budgetAlt.title: Wild swimming at Warren Wood
budgetAlt.description: Take a refreshing dip in the River Wye at Warren Wood, a popular local swimming spot (use caution).

stops.title: The Harp Inn, New Radnor
stops.description: A traditional pub with hearty lunches and local ales. Popular with walkers and kayakers.

budgetAlt.title: Packed lunch at Llyn Clywedog
budgetAlt.description: Enjoy your packed lunch overlooking the stunning views of Llyn Clywedog reservoir.

stops.title: Elan Valley Reservoirs Walk
stops.description: Explore the stunning landscape of the Elan Valley with a walk around the Craig Goch dam, taking in the scenery and spotting local wildlife.

wetAlt.title: Explore the Elan Valley Dams by car
wetAlt.description: Drive between the different dams and admire their architecture from the comfort of your car.

budgetAlt.title: Free - Picnic by the reservoirs
budgetAlt.description: Enjoy a picnic by the reservoirs.

stops.title: Elan Valley Hotel
stops.description: A comfortable hotel in the heart of the Elan Valley, perfect for exploring the area. Has a great restaurant and bar.

budgetAlt.title: Hafren Forest Hideaway (Hostel)
budgetAlt.description: A basic but affordable hostel in nearby Staylittle, surrounded by forest trails.

stops.title: SUP at Llyn Clywedog
stops.description: Enjoy a morning of stand-up paddleboarding on the calm waters of Llyn Clywedog. Stunning views guaranteed.

wetAlt.title: Visit the Centre for Alternative Technology
wetAlt.description: Explore sustainable living solutions at this interactive eco-centre near Machynlleth.

budgetAlt.title: Walking trail around Llyn Clywedog
budgetAlt.description: Take a scenic walk around the perimeter of the lake, enjoying the views and fresh air.

stops.title: Clywedog Sailing Club Cafe
stops.description: A small cafe with a fantastic view. Serves coffee, cakes, and light lunches.

budgetAlt.title: Picnic at Clywedog Dam
budgetAlt.description: Enjoy a packed lunch with panoramic views from the top of the Clywedog Dam.

stops.title: Wild Swimming at the base of Clywedog Dam
stops.description: A refreshing and invigorating experience with the backdrop of the largest concrete dam in Britain.

wetAlt.title: Devil's Bridge Falls
wetAlt.description: Explore the iconic waterfalls at Devil's Bridge (entry fee applies).

budgetAlt.title: Free - Waterfall Exploration
budgetAlt.description: Explore the trails around the base of the dam

knowBeforeYouGo.weather: Mid Wales weather is notoriously unpredictable. Pack for all conditions, even in summer. River levels can rise quickly after heavy rain, so check conditions before kayaking or swimming.
knowBeforeYouGo.traffic: Traffic can be heavy on weekends and during school holidays, especially on the A44 and A470. Parking at popular spots like Elan Valley and Llyn Clywedog can fill up quickly, arrive early or be prepared to walk.
knowBeforeYouGo.booking: It's essential to book kayaking tours in advance, especially during peak season. Accommodation in the Elan Valley also books up quickly. Pre-booking is highly recommended.
knowBeforeYouGo.fitness: A moderate level of fitness is required for this trip. Kayaking involves some upper body strength, and the Elan Valley walk includes some uphill sections. Swimming in rivers requires caution and competence.
